content:
Interesting Microsoft telling you about other applications having their own procedures and me first pointing you to their requirements to connect hey. But they like to deny responsibility.

First you need to make sure your incoming and outgoing server are as shown in this page https://support.microsoft.com/en-au/office/pop-imap-and-smtp-settings-for-outlook-com-d088b986-291d-42b8-9564-9c414e2aa040

Then, if you have to change the server names restart Thunderbird and return to the account settings. Change the authentication method to oauth in the incoming account and the outgoing server (SMTP) entry.
creator: MattAuSupport

content: well what is the response from iinet about why your ability to send mail has been blocked. I am not a customer, so I have no idea what they consider abuse.

content: It is simply, your recipients is paying this mob, antispamcloud (see https://my.azym.com/index.php/knowledgebase/39/Manage-AntispamCloud.html) to block and refuse spam emails. They have identified your mail as spam. I suggest you address your issues to the company blocking or your correspondents. There is certainly nothing that can be done here.
creator: MattAuSupport

content: Thanks. Losing them was my fear. A guess: if the account had been IMAP, what was on PC were just the headers, as IMAP downloads messages when opened and otherwise just downloads headers. To have all messages, one must set sync to all messages on folder (and even that needs periodic refreshing).

content:
Right-click the account highlighted in your picture, Subscribe, Refresh, and check the box for Junk (MS accounts use Junk instead of Spam or Bulk).

For the other account, open Account Settings, select the dormant account, then Account Actions at the bottom of the left pane, Remove Account. If Remove Account is greyed out, select another account, then Account Actions, Set as Default, then remove the dormant account.

If you want to keep the dormant mail, first copy it to a subfolder of Local Folders.

content: I presume you want version 115.13. That is at https://ftp.mozilla.org/pub/thunderbird/releases/115.13.0/ Just pick the desired version, such as Linux, win32 or win64 and then pick the language. Download over the current version. Then, check for a compatibilities.ini file in the resulting profile and delete it. However, if the concerns are minor, it may be better to stay and work through them, as 128 will be receiving regular updates.
creator: davidsk

content: I have a concern that possibly other items didn't transfer, since a transfer copies all folders. But, this should work: - click tools>import>importfromafile>importaddressbook>sqlitedatabasefile and then locate and select abook.sqlite from within the old profile.
creator: davidsk

content: - click 'account settings' - in left sidebar, highlight one of the accounts, scroll down slightly to see the 'Account Actions' menu on same side of screen. Click that an select 'remove account. That will include a box to check if you want messages to also be deleted. - repeat for the other account.

content:
Mike McGinnis said
It won't let me remove the account, the "remove account" text is faded. It will let me remove accounts that I want to keep!

The Default account can't be removed. Set another account as Default, with Account Actions, then remove the first account.

content:
The ldif and csv files are address books with the same date, and although both can be imported from Tools/Import, ldif is the native format and easier to import.

The Personal file is an mbox file and Personal.snm is the index, now replaced by an .msf file. Open TB, Help/Troubleshooting Info, Profile Folder, Open Folder, close TB, copy the mbox into Mail/Local Folders, restart TB and find the Personal folder under Local Folders in the Folder Pane.
